title: R44509
content: Member-constituent communications are essential in representative government, allowing for the flow of information between Members and constituents. This communication is crucial for citizens to make informed policy judgments and for congressional actions to reflect the interests of the governed. Throughout American history, the franking privilege facilitated this communication by allowing both Members and constituents to send mail free of charge. Technological advancements in the 19th and early 20th centuries, such as mass newspapers and the telephone, further aided in exchanging information. Until the late 20th century, communication between Members and constituents primarily consisted of postal mail, telephone calls, and press. The rise of electronic communications technology has transformed Member-constituent interactions, with traditional modes like postal mail and telephone calls being overshadowed by emails and online platforms like official websites, blogs, YouTube channels, and Facebook pages. This shift has significantly altered the way Members and constituents communicate, reducing costs and increasing reach. The rise of electronic communications technology has revolutionized Member-constituent interactions, allowing for instant and cost-effective communication. This has led to changes in how Members organize their offices, manage legislative activities, and engage with wider political and policy constituencies. The report is divided into five parts, discussing the role of constituent communications in a representative democracy, the current nature of electronic communications in Congress, and the impact of existing laws. Since the Continental Congress, constituent communications with elected representatives have evolved significantly. Changes in congressional communications technology can be categorized into historical communications, electronic communications, and social media. Constituent communications play a crucial role in representative government, with the franking privilege originating in the 17th century in the British House of Commons. The franking privilege, originating in the 17th century, allowed Members of Congress to send and receive mail for official communication purposes. This privilege was granted under various legislative acts, including the Post Office Act of 1792 and subsequent legislation that extended the use of the frank to specific time periods and types of mail. The act of 1825 also allowed for the unlimited franking of newspapers and congressional documents. During the late 18th and early 19th centuries, franked mail played a crucial role in national politics. Members of Congress used the postal system to distribute government information to citizens and local newspapers. The franking privilege allowed constituents to send letters to their Senators and Representatives for free, seen as a benefit to the constituents. President Andrew Jackson viewed the Post Office Department as essential to a democratic republic. The Department is crucial for diffusing knowledge and connecting the government with the people. Proponents of franking argue that it allows Members to inform constituents about important matters. Technological advancements in the late 19th and early 20th centuries aided in the exchange of information between Members and constituents. Until the late 20th century, Member-constituent communications mainly involved postal mail, telephone calls, press releases, and face-to-face meetings. Representatives and Senators adapted their communication methods based on media changes. Traditional forms of communication are still considered essential for the functioning of the representative system. Member-constituent communication is crucial for the functioning of the representative system. Representatives and Senators have various options to interact with constituents, including franking letters, long-distance calls, district travel, and electronic communication. New technologies like email, websites, and social media have significantly increased communication between Members and constituents. Email has become the preferred method of communication with Congress, showing a shift from traditional modes of communication. The volume of emails received by the House of Representatives and Senate has surpassed postal mail. Email communication with Congress has significantly increased since the late 1990s, while postal mail has decreased. Electronic communications have become the most common method for Members to communicate with constituents. The use of email communication by Members of Congress has increased significantly, surpassing postal mail as the most common method of communication with constituents. The cost of official mail from Congress has decreased to its lowest point since FY1954, with nominal mail costs declining over 60% in the past 12 years, likely due to a shift towards electronic communications. The adoption of social media by Members of Congress has increased significantly, with almost all Senators and Representatives having official Twitter and Facebook accounts by January 2013. Congressional committees have also started using social media platforms, with 90% of majority committees and 76% of minority committees having Twitter or Facebook accounts. The adoption of social media by Members of Congress has increased significantly, with almost all Senators and Representatives having official Twitter and Facebook accounts by January 2013. Surveys in 2015 found that YouTube, Instagram, and Flickr are also popular social media platforms among Members. This shift in communication has allowed for quicker dissemination of information and easier reach to constituents at a fixed cost. Members can now easily connect with a larger audience, including those who are not their own constituents. Electronic communications have virtually no direct marginal cost for Members of Congress and constituents, unlike traditional methods like postal mail and phone calls. This has removed financial constraints on communication, allowing for easier reach to a larger audience at a fixed cost. The near-zero cost of electronic communication between Members of Congress and constituents has eliminated direct financial constraints. This has led to an increase in the volume of communications, potentially influencing Members' ability to gauge the intensity of preferences. Studies suggest that social media may drive individuals towards one-sided news information, affecting the type of feedback Members receive. Electronic communications have revolutionized how Members of Congress interact with constituents, allowing for instant updates on floor activity and real-time contact. This has changed the speed and types of information shared between Members and constituents, compared to traditional forms of communication like faxed press releases. With the rise of electronic communications, constituents and Members can easily share information about amendments in real time, potentially changing how Members respond to constituent preferences. Social media allows for constant communication and specific preferences to be expressed on various issues, although it is unclear if these preferences represent the entire district or state. The rise of electronic communications has changed how Members of the House can reach constituents. While traditional mail was limited to their districts, electronic tools like email and social media now allow Members to interact with a wider audience. This shift presents challenges for Members who prefer to communicate only with constituents in their district or state. The House and Senate have adopted social media policies for Representatives and Senators to use official resources appropriately. The Committee on House Administration defines social media accounts as profiles on third-party sites. Members can establish these accounts as long as they maintain their official position. Regulations may evolve as social media continues to evolve. House regulations require Members to clearly state their official position in social media account names. Material posted on official accounts must comply with Federal law and House Rules, and be relevant to official duties. Members can use official funds for expenses related to official websites and third-party social media presence. The Senate Internet Policy sets rules for Senators using social media for official business. The Senate Rules Committee evaluates and approves third-party social media platforms for official use by Senators. Once approved, a "Dear Colleague" letter is issued with any necessary information or requirements. In 2013, Vine was formally approved. The use of the congressional franking privilege is regulated by federal law and House and Senate rules. The use of social media platforms by Members of Congress is not directly affected by franking regulations, as social media communications do not require postal mail. However, some forms of social media use, such as electronic advertisements purchased with Member Representational Allowance (MRA) funds, may be subject to advisory opinions and regulations regarding timing and content from the House Commission on Congressional Mailing Standards. For example, a "promoted" tweet on Twitter could be considered an unsolicited mass communication and must adhere to franking regulations. The adoption of social media by congressional offices presents new opportunities for communication with constituents and wider audiences. This shift to electronic communications brings challenges in office operations, communication strategies, and constituent representation. Members of Congress have the flexibility to organize and staff their offices, but the use of social media impacts how constituent expectations are met and staff are allocated. Speedier communication with constituents is a potential benefit of electronic communications adoption. The adoption of social media by congressional offices has increased the potential for faster communication with constituents, leading to higher expectations for rapid responses. While email allows for quicker communication similar to postal mail, social media presents even greater challenges in office operations due to the expectation of instantaneous interactions. Social media has accelerated the sharing of information and expanded the reach of messages. The adoption of social media by congressional offices has increased the potential for faster communication with constituents, leading to higher expectations for rapid responses. Interacting with constituents on social media requires continuous monitoring to meet expectations for timely responses. The speed of communications on social media can impact the dissemination of information. Members need to adapt to the fast-paced nature of social media communication, requiring concise messaging within platform limits. Allocation of staff resources reflects Members' priorities, balancing constituent service, communications, legislative, and oversight responsibilities. The rise of electronic communications adds pressure to these allocation decisions. The increase in electronic communications has added pressure to staff resource allocation in congressional offices. Social media usage is growing, with some offices dedicating staff specifically for social media tasks. Existing staff levels may or may not be sufficient to handle interactive social media engagement with constituents. The rise of electronic communications and social media has created opportunities and challenges for congressional offices. The number of incoming emails to Congress has increased significantly due to the ease and low cost of electronic communication. Managing communications with a large audience and deciding on the real-time pace of engagement are key concerns for offices. The rise of electronic communications and social media has changed how constituents interact with Congress. While postal mail used to indicate strong opinions, electronic communications have lowered the intensity threshold for expressing preferences. Social media offers real-time data for understanding constituent thinking, but monitoring it requires staff resources. Congressional offices face challenges in deciding what content to cover due to the speed of social media. The rise of electronic communications and social media has revolutionized how constituents engage with Congress. Social media allows for real-time discussions on amendments, enabling Members to interact with the public before committee votes. This real-time communication offers the potential for increased information sharing between Members and constituents, as well as the opportunity for Members to educate their constituents quickly and effectively. Using real-time communications in social media can be faster but lacks nuance and context. It leaves little time for reflection and may set expectations for future engagement. Social media allows for traditional information sharing but also enables real-time conversations between legislators and constituents. Studies show a shift towards more interactive activities on platforms like Twitter by Members of Congress. The shift towards more interactive activities on social media platforms like Twitter by Members of Congress presents challenges in formalizing interactivity protocols and setting expectations for two-way interactions between legislators and constituents. Social media enables two-way interactions and allows constituents to engage with each other, presenting strategic decisions for Members on handling information generated by constituents. Government agencies have implemented guidelines for social media use, including rules on posting, responding to comments, and content timeliness. The General Services Administration's (GSA's) social media policy, similar to DOI's, emphasizes official communications following records management practices and agency sanctioning. The House of Representatives and Senate have overarching social media policies focusing on constituent communications and official resource use. Individual Members may have their own social media policies within these guidelines. Some Members of Congress have created their own social media policies, including disclaimers and commenting guidelines on their official pages. These policies aim to set limits on what can be posted and require enforcement to monitor inappropriate comments. It is important for Representatives and Senators to treat all constituents equally, regardless of political viewpoints. The adoption of social media is changing the nature of representation for Members of Congress by granting users potential anonymity and presenting challenges in interacting with geographic constituents. Social media policies could impact the enforcement of rules like franked mail regulations. The rise of electronic communications and social media has increased opportunities for surrogate representation, where Members represent constituents outside their district based on shared characteristics. Prior to this, few Members engaged in such activities due to resource limitations. Electronic communications have leveled the playing field, allowing even rank-and-file Members to gather a national following to advance their agendas. The rise of electronic communications and social media has leveled the playing field for Members of Congress, allowing them to gather a national following and advance their policy objectives at virtually no financial cost. This has given Congress a more influential voice in public political debates compared to the President. The evolution of constituent communications with elected representatives has been influenced by the rise of social media. This has expanded the scope of individuals that Members of Congress can communicate with, creating unique challenges and opportunities. The use of social media as a communication tool has implications for representation due to its public nature and differences from traditional forms of communication like postal mail and email. Social media posts are public, unlike private mail and email conversations. Hidden costs may be associated with using social media, such as data ownership by third-party software. Public managers face challenges with constant platform changes and emergent citizen behavior. Congressional data on non-congressional servers raises privacy concerns, leading to the establishment of policies for third-party website use. Privacy concerns exist in the online world, with information posted on social media potentially visible to everyone. The House and Senate have developed privacy policies to guide Representatives and Senators on website content, reminding users that posted information is public. Using social media can enhance a Member's political profile and influence public policy, although the broader implications of adopting social media remain unclear. Some Members of Congress are using social media to engage broader audiences for their policy and political goals. While traditional district and state representation remains important, social media may complicate the relationship between national and local issues.
